subject: Re: [junit] Clarifying how to use unit tests
msgSnippet: ... Interface:  absolutely. Implementation:  depends. Ideally, the business logic of your test should run against the interface exclusively and which
messageBody:
On 12/8/05, Rakesh Patel <rakesh.mailgroups@...> wrote:
>
>
> So here's my initial design.
>
> public interface PostcodeService {
> public String getAddressAsXML(String postcode);
> }
>
> now, should I write a test class against the
> interface(PostcodeServiceTest) or against the implementation
> class(PostcodeServiceImplTest)?


Interface: absolutely.
Implementation: depends.

Ideally, the business logic of your test should run against the interface
exclusively and which implementation is being used can then be decided at
setUp time, via dependency injection or data providers:

private PostCodeService m_postCodeService;

@Configuration(beforeTestClass = true)
public void classSetUp() {
m_postCodeService = new PostCodeServiceImpl();
}

@Test
public void verifyAddressAsXml(String postCode) {
m_postCodeService.foo(postCode);
// assert
}

In this example, classSetUp() hardcodes the implementation to be used but
you could imagine making this more flexible (depending on a parameter, a
test group, etc...). Also, separating your tests from your set up (e.g.
base class / child class) will give you even more flexibility to switch
implementations at runtime without altering the business logic that tests
your interface.



> I am spending way too long thinking about this rather than writing code
> which has me a bit worried.


Sometimes, spending a lot of time thinking about a problem causes you to
write less code in the end. Hopefully, this is one of these cases :-)
